head.supplied: ¶ Memorandum, conveying in a few words my views on the ascent of the Ker Ranges. It might be accomplished at a ¶ trifling expense by land ¶ from Cashmere Police station, thus not requiring subsidie...

div.p: Z71/6756, unit 576, VPRS 3991/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

To proof.
Memorandum, conveying in a few words my views on the ascent of the Ker Ranges. It might be accomplished at a trifling expense by land from Cashmere Police station, thus not requiring subsidies from here. It would be important for geographic purposes, geologic and mineralogic exploration; it would certainly open new resources to Queensland, and would give the collector of the botanic Garden a favorable line for operations. My views in detail explained in the letter.
See M to W. Odgers, 6 May 1871.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; font-size: 12pt; margin-left: 1.75in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: 0in;

div.p:
27/5/71.
McCulloch minuted on this letter [no date]: 'If the prepared expedition is [further/fuller] thought of [&] [mentioned] — certainly it will not be of any [… loss] in this Colony — It will no doubt be undertaken by that Colony — in any case a portion of such expenditure will be borne by Victoria'.
